name: Microservices
description: Group related features and domains in microservices applying Domain Driven Design strategic patterns. Consider EventStorming to identify your business process and domains. Be aware of the https://www.infoq.com/news/2017/12/entity-services-antipattern/ anti-pattern.

name: Domain Driven Design (DDD)
description: Usage of DDD to define our domains and services. Thereby we focus primarily on strategic patterns. EventStorming is one preferred way to visualize and identify domains and services.

name: Micro Frontends
description: We are using Module Federation to shorten our release times and force squads to think and implement in independent modules.

name: Resilience Patterns
description: Use common resilience patterns as applicable to make our services resilience against common failure scenarios.

name: Infrastructure As Code (IaC)
description: We define our infrastructure in machine readable configuration files for a high level of automation. This also allows us to define and control security, compliance requirements in a central place, fostering security-by-design and compliance-by-design.

name: Feature Toggles
description: Usage of feature toggles to enable/disable feature, e.g. for A/B testing, on-boarding of features, etc. Feature toggles shall not be used once a feature is general available. This is the configured via the respective permissions and application configuration.

name: Application Performance Monitoring (APM)
description: Use Application Performance Monitoring to gain insight in the performance and usability of our products and services in a standardized way. Thereby we combine APM data with other information, e.g. trace, metrics and log data to get a holistic view of our services.

name: API First
description: We apply the API first principle for all our product API and follow API guidelines.

name: split.io
description: We use split.io as our feature toggle service.

name: Helm
description: We use Helm to define our Kubernetes deployments.

name: Renovate
description: We use Renovate to automatically manage dependency updates to speed up update cycles in order to keep our software reasonable up-to-date. This also is crucial in case of security update where a quick and fast response time is crucial.

name: Typescript
description: We only allow Typescript for new projects and migrate old ones if they are further used in production.

name: NextJS
description: We implement our Interhyp website using Next.js.

name: Kafka Schema Registry
description: We use the Kafka Schema Registry to manage and document the contract for all messages we send over Kafka.

name: Openshift
description: We migrate to a standardized and plain vanilla Kubernetes environment, e.g. Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) and Kubermatic.

name: Kubernetes
description: We use plain Kubernetes distributions in favor of proprietary bundles to service our mortgage platform.

name: ArgoCD
description: We use ArgoCD as our GitOps continuous delivery tool for Kubernetes to manage the lifecycle of applications in Kubernetes.

name: Apache Kafka
description: Apache Kafka is our standard messaging/event broker and event store.

name: istio
description: Istio is our preferred Service Mesh framework.

name: Kotlin
description: We use Kotlin as our secondary JVM based language as Kotlin is less error-prone (inherently null-safe) than java while beeing 100% compatible, needing less boilerplate code, easy to learn and generally the more modern language.

name: Nginx
description: We use Nginx as our preferred web server, (reverse) proxy in the Microservice landscape as required.

name: MongoDB
description: MongoDB is a well-proven document NoSQL database. First uses cases are in the submission and bid domain.

name: linkerd
description: We have decided for Istio as our preferred Service Mesh framework

name: Azure API Management
description: Currently under evaluation for the Partner APIs to provide a central documentation hub for our APIs.

name: Golang
description: We use Golang for helper applications, tools and extensions for the Kubernetes ecosystem. We don't use Golang for regular Mortgage Platform microservices.

name: Swagger API
description: Swagger API/Openshift < 2.0 shall not be used anymore and replaced with the latest version of OpenAPI.

name: OpenAPI
description: OpenAPI in version 3 and newer has become the defacto standard for REST APIs and shall be used in a API First approach for all our REST(like) APIs.

name: Node.js
description: Node.js can be used for BFFs and very small services with little business logic and which are self-contained and don't need other services and/or storages.

name: Express
description: Express is the defacto mainstream application framework for Node.js.

name: Web Components
description: Web Components are not fully compatible with Toolsets and do not add any value to our current toolbox.

name: Salesforce Sales Cloud
description: Salesforce Sales Cloud is currently only used as a technical middle layer to integrate with the Salesforce Marketing Cloud.

name: Hazelcast
description: Hazelcast can be used as a distributed caching mechanism. Already used as local cache in HVB project.

name: Grafana
description: Grafana is our one-stop-shop for all metrics to be visualized stored in Prometheus.

name: Prometheus
description: Prometheus and AlertManager for holistic collection of metrics and alerting,

name: Terragrunt
description: Terragrunt is a thin wrapper that provides extra tools for keeping your configurations DRY, working with multiple Terraform modules, and managing remote state.

name: Kustomize
description: We are migrating to Helm to our preferred solution for Kubernetes customization and configuration.

name: Elastic Operator
description: Elastic Operator provides a modern Kubernetes compatible way to operate  the Elastic stack.
